conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start from rest at the same time and position, moving in the same direction. Their motion is described by a velocity-time (v-t) graph.
In a v-t graph, the slope of the line gives the acceleration, and the area under the curve gives the displacement.
Particle A starts accelerating from t=0 to t=t₀, reaching a velocity of 2v₀, and then decelerates to zero by t=2t₀.
Particle B accelerates from t=0 to t=4t₀, reaching a velocity of v₀, remains at v₀ until t=5t₀, and then decelerates to zero by t=6t₀.

premise: Particle A starts from rest at t=0 and reaches a velocity of 2v₀ at t=t₀.
Particle B starts from rest at t=0 and reaches a velocity of v₀ at t=4t₀.
The accelerations are a_A = 2v₀ / t₀ and a_B = v₀ / 4t₀.
The slope of the v-t graph for A is twice that of B.
conclusion: The ratio of the accelerations of A and B is 2:1.
